replies.author: @ddandymann
replies.text:
@alexantone5532 Not if they have gone through male puberty before transitioning. Male puberty causes both muscle mass and bone density to increase dramatically and once they have increased they cannot be decreased no matter how many hormones you flood the body with.

The issue here is that there is also a strong ethical argument against allowing minors to make life altering choices, such as using hormone therapy at an early age, 11-13, to prevent male puberty.  Its a really screwed up world that allows kids to permanently change their body composition before they hit their teens but doesn't allow them to drink or vote until 18-21.

replies.author: @mothsforeyes
replies.text:
@ddandymann 
Is there though?
We alter children's bodies or neurological development drastically to treat all kinds of conditions. Treating a child with radiotherapy for cancer, dexamphetamines for behavioural problems, etc. Even things like weight lifting and ballet can have lifelong impacts on a person's body if they begin too young, like stunted growth and disrupted menstral cycles.
You've shown you are aware that early transitioning (or at the very least suspending puberty) would be a solution to the problem you introduced about male puberty and women's sport, but any issues that a child might have to face with early transitioning (like possible sterility, higher risks of cancer, permanent bodily chages) are not comparable to voting or recreational alcohol consumption, they're comparable to conditions that require medical intervention - and even that is not exactly true, because over medicalising trans issues itself is dehumanising.
Drinking and voting are social pivileges, granted by law at certain ages (but even then, sometimes with caveats).

Forgive me if this seems uncharitable, but the only inference I can read from your comments is: how little autonomy, both bodily and socially, do we tolerate trans women specifically to have.

replies.author: @ddandymann
replies.text:
@mothsforeyes I'm sorry but how are side effects including 'possible sterility, higher risks of cancer, permanent bodily changes' not comparable to recreational alcohol consumption? All three of those are side effects of excessive alcohol consumption, the key difference being that in hormone therapy the chances of both the former and latter of those possibilities are higher than with alcohol consumption.

Hormone Therapy is physiological treatment for a psychological condition, note that I am using that term in the literal sense rather than the derogatory sense, that can have serious long term repercussions on a childs physical well being. 

Here is where I will cross the line to a line of argument that some may consider offensive but is none the less factually based and necessary to the debate surrounding this issue. Children go through phases, I know this sounds like an old clich√© yet it is true none the less and something I can speak to through personal experience. I myself am bisexual and when I was a teen and grappling with this I felt a lot of pressure to either come out as completely gay or to not come out at all, neither of which would have made me any happier in the long term. After initially coming out as gay and feeling no better for it my parents took me to a specialist guidance councillor to help me work through my confusion and the social pressures.

If a child was in the a similar position to me but weighing up which gender they are most happy being the current protocol would encourage them to start hormone therapy. In that case a child who is not yet completely sure of their decision could feel pressured in to making a choice that they are not yet sure is right for them. The difference is that for that child there would be long term physical consequences to this that I did not suffer from wrongly coming out as gay. Should this child, over time, come to realise they were pressured or rushed into a making the wrong decision then the long term psychological effects of this could be terrible.

My belief is that children who are feeling confused, again in the literal sense, about their gender should always be given psychological treatment first to help them ensure they make the right decision. Of course this treatment would have to be completely pressure free and designed to just help the child work through their own thoughts and feelings without being pushed one way or the other. Only once this process is complete should they be able to start physical treatment.

The issue is that this view, one rooted out of concern for the childs well being, is often dismissed and derided as transphobic by trans activists, seeking to shut it out of the discussion for reasons I can only speculate at. Currently the entire debate seems to hinge more around not offending the trans community, an impossibility when it comes to the more militant members, rather than ensuring children's well being. Something which I am, quite frankly, disgusted by.

replies.author: @evelcustom9864
replies.text: More accurately maybe it's that when we design algorithms we focus only on the positives they may bring and fail to predict the problems. It's like social media as a whole. There are countless benefits to it in the way it can bring people together and open up new knowledge and experience and simultaneously major problems of social bubbles and amplification of the loudest and most radical views. Fighting against social media or algorithms as a whole is like trying to stop a coming tide. We must step back, assess where we are at, fix what we can, and then deal with the unforseen problems of the fixes we implemented. To quote BSG "All of this has happened before, and all of this will happen again".

replies.author: @spacecadet9663
replies.text: @pablowall I understand the confusion on your part. Most people assume neoliberal and liberalism (as  americans tends to use liberalism to mean more broadly left-wing beliefs nowadays) are the same thing, but they aren't. The main thrust of neoliberalism began with Republican president Ronald Reagan (who definitely wasn't at all liberal as we'd use the term today) and was based around a global push for economic globalization, deregulation and privatization of almost all industries, and austerity at home with the cutting of the welfare state and other entitlement spending. Elsewhere this ideology came to be known as Neoliberalism, as it was a resurrection of the 19th century liberalism of pre-world war one Britain. We in America came to know it simply as conservatism, as the neoliberal ideology came to supplant and replace the conservatism of the period prior to Reagan's election in 1980. This is partly why the "center right" party in Australia is called the Liberal party while what we would consider their "center left" party is called the Labor party as it is in Britain and New Zealand. It think it's important to view Neoliberalism as inherently an economic theory and system of late stage capitalism, whereas what Americans have come to know as liberalism is an amalgam of the old guard labor movement built up during the first half of the twentieth century, with the reforms of the new deal as the culmination of the labor movements aims. Add to that the social integration that was the bed rock of the civil rights movement in the sixties and what you have is the modern American view of Liberalism (either as a broad stand in for leftist theory or as an alternative to it, as many centrist liberals in America would paint their ideological beliefs). Sorry for the long response, and I hope this helped clear away any confusion over the matter.

William Pitt the Younger would be Alt-Right.
Oliver Cromwell would be. Even the Liberal Nationalists that utilised Nationalism against European Monarchism would be Alt-Right.

 Note: Burke distinguished Old from New Whigs on the basis of for/against the French Revolution.
Old Whigs - Against
New Whigs - For

 The label Alt-Right died in 2016/17 The only people to use the word are Leftists or the what remains of the actual Alt-Right.

When you define your "centre" as what you are against, you are not 'for' anything. 
Now you are where you are because you found your centre.  
There is no such thing as deradicalisation. The term is defined in its use. A Leftist who converts people to Leftism is not deradicalising, but radicalising.  Likewise a Rightist is only radicalising, not deradicalising. 
The word deradicalise is only used by the Rightist/Leftist when converting people to their side.

Last of all; No I am not a centrist.
I started watching Anti-SJW content back when I was already aware of which "side" I stood. My ideological journey began at AS Level Politics surrounded by Corbyn supporters, Lib Dem supporters and Bernie Bros. I felt comfortable with One Nation conservatism (though now don't believe that it exists a form of conservatism - only exclusive to Disraeli) before flipping to mix Traditional conservatism with Libertarianism. 
This occured while I was watching Peter Hitchens. 
At the time I was getting stuck into Edmund Burke, Rothbard, Lord Acton - (Paleo-Libertarianism). Hoppe and Hans Adam II were my later influences during and after the A-level exams. 
Before I made my way to Paleo-Libertarianism I had already gotten sick of Sargon and the Anti-SJWs.
SJW Cringe compilations are comedy gold when you are bored. 
Nigel Farage and Peter Hitchens bashing Leftist and EU bureaucrat compilations are endlessly funny - in my opinion. Although I didn't take an interest in Peter Hitchens through that.  I watched him take part in debates, listened to talks and started reading his books - The Aboltion of Britain - On Roy Jenkins and the social reform, Television, the war on Grammar schools, British identity and so on.
 Brief History of Crime/Abolition of Liberty - On the attack on British Liberties, the attack on Robert Peel's police force in favour of a Modern Police force (Roy Jenkins again) and so on.

 I watch Vee, Sargon and Louis today but I have my own stances, agreements and disagreements.

The answer to this question of falling down the Anti-SJW, Alt-Right or Breadtube rabbit hole lies here. It depends on whether you have a philosophical centre or not. 
If you have you will be like me. I watch content from all of these communities. If not, you will be stuck in an echochamber rabbit hole. I seek to convert no one. Each to their own in their journey.

replies.text:
@comrademuds1951 it is. They knew they would grab the wtitter/tumblr audience and so icluded as much representation as they could handle. And yes,this is kinda a critique of capitalism,as it rewarded disney with a huge amount of money as they milked the franchise,not caring about telling a good story as timeless as the ogs or deep as the prequels,instead focusing on name recegnition,dramatic trailers and marketeble toys for hasbro to sell.
It shows capitalism at its worst,as a huge corporation gets a hold on a successfull ip try to fit it into their successfull formula(mcu). They give the first movie to mr spectacle,who makes a nostaligia driven movie that is full of conveniences,plotholes,and unnecessery action scenes to distract you from all that. It also has no contreversy,fiting into the current political climate almost too nicely. It also anwsers as litle questions as possible,guarranteing an audience for the next movie and also not locking the story into a rigid path,because they dont know where it is going. The novelty of seeing a star wars movie,a monopoly on the experience if you will,blinds some and disney being a big corporation,a lot of peaple want to keep ties with them and bombard them with praise. On the other end you have peaple who critisize the movie to be cool and some that maybe saw that something was wrong. After that,they realised that the first movie was so transparently corprete, if they made the second one just like it,peaple would see these movies as what they are:predictable cashgrabs. Some guy in the board remembered,that before star wars george lucas was an indie director known for experimental movies and thought they would use this formula to get star wars to work. They hire rian johnson,a guy who is known for twists and turns,has never handled a serees of films before and has very little understanding of the source material who would also have his ego boosted due to you know,directing an official star wars movie. Now,after this some peaple would say that rian needed some guys who handled a franchise,a guy who knows the source material ecs,to keep him in check and make sure his movie doe not conflict with the films before and cooporates with the films after,so inserting it into tha cannon would not cause any problems. Disney gave him full controll over the script and direction. They might have also told him,that they really like his twist and turns and would really love to see that. The product is a middle finger to anyone invested in the stra wars universe,as it destroed the intreage of the force awakens,conflicts with preexisting sourse materiall also ties up every loose end,leaving the film afterwards with very few options. The internet reaction was of course,very divisive:you had the "fans",peaple who were inveasted into the stories one way or another,trashing the film. In the other side you had avarige moviegoers,peaple who like all things starwars and the guys who want to appeal to disney alongside some critics who liked the good parts more than they disliked the bad parts defending it on twitter. The two sides both had extremists,which they used as ammunition against each other,painting the other side as bootlikers,toxic,dumb ecs. Add politics into the mix and i think making a film more devidive than this one will be a very hard. With a lot of the community angry,disney realised they needed the final chapter to unite the fanbase. They addad palpatine,made ray a palpatine,made ray train,repaired kulos helmet ecs. They also addad a lot of dight scenes,reylo and all that to pleese the general audience. The thing is,adter the last jedi,moviegoers,the actors and evryone else where more cynical,more suspocios and they saw the signs from the trailers,they saw the marketing,they saw exactly what disney was trying to do. Because of this,the film  did unite the star waes community,as noone liked it. After disney mcu-ed star wars and spammed movies,it has lost its novelty. With kids not buying new toys,the last movie in peaces and EA screwing up twise, the only parts of star wars still enjoyed are sjows like the clone wars and mandalorian,alongside EA games,when they are under preassure and kept in check by disney pr or something. The fact that they managed to lose money with solo and make movies that unite all branches of the community to hate you while ticking off every point in the things that can go wrong list just shows that being driven by profit alone produces some of the worst movies off all time.

@poweroffriendship2.0 The issue is that ANTI-SJW‚Äôs conflate a radfems desire to put men in their place with the representation of characters like Captain Marvel and Rey. And this is because of cringe pop feminism that is aggressive in how it was to destroy the patriarchy. The thing is that optics matter on both sides (yea I‚Äôm doing the both sides things). And when you have unironic angry radfems with dyed hair acting in that manner it‚Äôs easy to connect the two together and create a narrative like this. It doesn‚Äôt help that allot of liberal types on Twitter back this by saying if you dislike the new Star Wars or dislike Rey or Holdo, you‚Äôre an Incel that can‚Äôt get a woman to love you. 

I think in some ways both things can be true. I think that cringe feminist ideals can lead to characters like Rey while also just being a product of corporate lazy writing as well. Because of this I can‚Äôt fully go anti reactionary because then it‚Äôd feel like I‚Äôm having a blind spot due to my bias. So instead I‚Äôd rather use this as way to tell people that yes Rey sucks ass but that doesn‚Äôt mean diversity is a zero sum game because a female character happens to be strong.

However, when it comes to Star Wars, it's a complicated issue. Maybe it would've been better if Finn is the main character of the sequel and not Rey. Rey is actually a fine character when I got first introduced to the sequels but as sequels progressed, I started to get annoyed. When it comes to that, I kinda feel sorry for Daisy Ridley about her backlash of her poor performance, so does John Boyega. As what "skeptical" as it sounds, the anti-SJWs are either against or praise John Boyega out of spite to Disney and Lucasfilm. I am mildly confused for that.

I mean, the issue is not the political ideology that snuck up into every medium of storytelling, but it's because of the poor screenwriting and execution that the company managed to come up.

replies.text:
Edmund Spenser As I said, both are political approaches which in the final analysis are fundamentally concerned with maintaining private property over the means of production; that is, maintaining the capitalist mode of production. Locke and Mill are pretty far removed from the time when Fascism was even a thing and, more importantly, from the time when a socialist revolution actually took power.

Would you like, however, some quotes on how favorably Fascism was viewed by celebrated liberal politicians and thinkers at the time when they were really afraid of a socialist revolution, namely the only thing that was a threat to capitalism?

Here's what Churchill has to say to signor Mussolini in 1927: "If I had been an Italian I am sure that I should have been whole-heartedly with you from the start to finish in your triumphant struggle against the bestial appetite and passions of Leninism. Externally your movement has rendered a service to the whole world".

And here is that other famous quote by von Mises: "It cannot be denied that Fascism and similar movements aimed at the establishment of dictatorships are full of the best intentions and that their intervention has for the moment saved European civilization. The merit that Fascism has thereby won for itself will live on eternally in history." Then he adds that he really views Fascism as an emergency measure, not as a permanent thing: "But though its policy has brought salvation for the moment, it is not of the kind which could promise continued success. Fascism was an emergency makeshift. To view it as something more would be a fatal error". 

Which is to say, when the going got tough, when the workers started realizing they didn't really need a minority of parasites stealing the lion's share of the wealth they produced with their own labor, capitalists and liberals conveniently forgot all that flowery liberal talk and just unleashed their thugs. Examples of this in 20th century history are way too many to list and this is already way too long of a post. 

Assuming you are interested in more and not simply outraged at my impertinent statements (!), you could search for "The Dark Side of Liberalism" series here on Youtube. It is in my opinion a generally good introduction on the subject.

replies.author: @HariKrishnan-kx1is
replies.text:
@m0za1x That's a very simplistic solution to quite a complicated problem. We wouldn't be in this mess if everyone was actually capable of fully independent thought. In fact people pick up so much from each other and their environment that even if you think you are thinking for yourself, you are probably not. Not to mention our inherent tribal tendencies to form in-groups and out-groups.

Left and right are just labels. But if you're only listening to one side of the thought spectrum which makes you increasingly paranoid and resentful towards certain sections of society, then listening to an opposing point of view can open your eyes to internal prejudices that you might not even have noticed. Provided you are actually interested in self improvement, and not deluding yourself.

@Furebel
replies.text:
‚Äã@griffin123122  The thing is, there is no "show more" button, even on this comment. Might be a bug. I found a way to get around it just using notification on my phone, but I already swiped out notification for your previous comment, so I can't get back to it.

I had people search through any of my activity, even googling me, or trying to search for my nickname in other social media, so I assumed you just found my other comments, as your reply made little to no sense for me.
So you just want me to explain why I think it is just another rabbit hole on level of other two barracks? You could just ask, you know?
First of all, the video is about anti-sjw being another extreme, with people falling into this rabbit hole believing that it is the reality, and teaches to think for yourself and form your own opinion, not dictated by others. And yet top comments here are people acting just like what author warned against - blindly absorbing everything they say, praising names of youtubers who criticize anti-sjws, acting like everyone who criticizes them must be "evil", and the worst part, that I can't even say neither about SJWs nor anti-sjws, is that so far people I discussed with feel like they ascended into some kind of higher state of mind, feeling so much above anyone else, one of them even said that yes, anti-anti-sjw simply always have moral high ground. Hence why I compared it to flat-earthers. Add up to that the fact, that these youtubers really do the same thing as anti-sjws (not saying that is necessarily bad, their message is good, I blame the people for not misreading the message), they just target next chain.

Of course as I said before, if I am wrong, feel free to correct me. I don't want to "win" a discussion, as this is impossible, I want to learn more, and possibly not make a mistake. So your honest opinion about it would be appreciated.

As for victimizing myself, you blew it out of proportions. I still don't know how you see me victimizing myself here, I meant to say that to form a group of support sounds stupid. Anti-anti-sjws (I'll just call it like that for convinience) are not bullied, discriminated, or don't need any support from what I seen. Neither do Anti-sjws, nor Sjws, this is just part of  political side really, why the hell would there need to be a support group? If anything, that just sounds like victimizing, but I would rather call this idea just stupid, and just ensures me in my opinion that this is just another rabbit hole.

Now sorry if I make some things hard to understand, english is not my native, and I always have troubles with wording my thoughts. So If I made something unclear, just ask instead of jumping out with judgement right away.

replies.author: @griffin123122
replies.text:
@Furebel Right, YouTube is weird. The only thing you missed from the first comment was me explaining why a community like that would potentially interest me, but I'll just explain again in a second.

Typically if you're making a good faith claim about something, you should provide your reasoning upfront. Assuming you were making the claim in good faith, I'll apologize for being blunt due to my personal experiences with people online.

In regards to the people here, it looks like the top comments are mostly people just making jokes and sometimes there's discourse in the replies. I dont know, I've definitely had issues with people being progressive and really fucking arrogant about it but it bothers me less due to my experience having grown up in the southern us. 

Given english isnt your main language I'm going to assume us geopolitical politics isnt something you know by heart, so to be brief the south essentially fetishizes being conservative and a lot of them love anti-sjw stuff. Independent actors feeling good about themselves for wanting rights for other people just doesnt bother me anymore.

When I said you played the victim, you are aware the term predates internet identity politics stuff, right? By saying that, I was basically saying that even though you thought the reaction to what you said was out of proportion, it was fair given what I had seen of you.

To explain why, let me explain my experience with being super into anti-SJW stuff in the last half of high school. I have never in my life been immersed in so much unashamed hatred towards other people. A *common* insult towards women was that they "wouldn't even rape her." 

Then eventually I kinda realized the world wasn't just that little bubble and I started hating myself most of all, because of the things I had been participating in. I dont really hate myself anymore for it, but at first it was so tempting to just go back and immerse myself in it. A group of people who had done something similar would have been nice, just to help me understand that I wasn't a bad person. So when you come in to a thread and dismiss the idea and say that actually you're being just as bad as those people, it just hurts.
I don't think I'm going to reply again, but hopefully it shed a bit of light on why some people can get so emotional about this

replies.author: @Furebel
replies.text:
‚Äã@griffin123122 Thanks for clarification on all of this.

You're right, I'm not too much into politics, overall, tho I've seen enough of SJW, left vs right, orange man bad controversies on the internet. You can't avoid it on the internet. However I don't think that even something as ridiculous as fetishizing conservatism is necessarily bad if handled properly. I'm sure it is as stupid as it sounds, but I think everyone has right to their own opinion, as long as they respect others opinions. It is the disrespect, and stupidity that should be targeted for the criticism, not political ideology.

I think my definition of victimization is different from yours. Nothing much to say about that.

Well I get that there are people who might have suddenly realized they were doing bad things, but that still does not protect them from getting criticism for what they do now, especially when they just jumped from one horse to another without changing behavior. And considering I had some discussions with other people (like the guy who literally said they have moral highground because), these sound to me like they are at most half-jokes.

author: @gabriellegoodwin4422
text:
I unironically became an Anti-SJW because I hated myself.  I was queer, and a woman and I was not in a good place mentally.  Having people give me reasons to hate myself, and justify my own suicidal thoughts was the closest I ever came to self harming.  The best thing that ever happened to me was (funnily enough) going on TikTok and finding a community of people just like me who explained how I wasn‚Äôt evil or sick for being this way.  
I‚Äôve met a lot of women and minorities who are Anti-SJWs, and while it‚Äôs sort of a meme to say that they must hate themselves, I do believe that most of the time it is true.  Anti-SJW commentators pray on peoples insecurities and self hatred to fuel a culture war that they‚Äôre losing.  
A bit of a rant, but it‚Äôs hard to talk to people about this, especially because it‚Äôs so taboo to admit to having been conservative in most liberal circles.

No extremes anymore. Two parties exist exclusively to get us to fight. I'm done with it.

author: @yaro8860
text:
I was 14 when I started watching Atheist videos. Then many of those channels suddenly started doing anti-feminism videos and I totally bought into this mentality that feminism is about men-hating and whining and having no reason to exist since "women in the modern world face no discrimination". Like Sargon, I only experienced this bad feminism on the internet without actually thinking about what they said or looking up sources myself. I wanted to be a cool anti-feminist woman like shoeonhead, like a little girl who wants to play with the boys.
This went on for about a year and I went to other sites to parrot the worldviews these youtubers had. I was directly challenged by feminists and had to acknowledge that I didn't think for myself, that it wasn't logic and skepticism that lead me to the views I held, but emotions ironically enough. But of course I couldn't just acknowledge I was an idiot, I held onto these views as if my life depended on it, tried to research why I and the youtubers I watched were right, tried to show the feminists I was debating with that they were wrong. Everything I searched for however showed me that my views were unfounded, that I was wrong.
It was humiliating and humbling but I think it led me to be a more sceptic person who can actually think for herself.

And now I find channels like shaun, hbomberguy, contrapoints and Lindsay Ellis and I just wish i had watched them earlier when I was in my anti-sjw phase.

replies.author: @KingBobXVI
replies.text:
The funny thing about all these "skeptic" channels who "don't care about feelings" is that they rarely cite sources and always make appeals to emotion, and get really mad when you contradict them, despite them saying they advocate for skepticism.
This is why a lot of content from people like Dan/Three Arrows, Shaun, etc always pick a specific argument from a specific person. Instead of saying, "Anti-SJW's say xyz" and ragging on xyz, they _show you_ the specific argument being made _by_ a self-proclaimed anti-SJW, and attack that specific argument. It avoids the alternative of strawmanning, which the conservative channels almost exclusively fall into.
Also I highly recommend Big Joel and Thoughtslime if you haven't seen them yet.

replies.author: @ddandymann
replies.text:
@EmElGeePro270 Please don't call people fascist who don't follow the ideology, it makes the term valueless. To paraphrase George Orwell from 60 years ago 'No one knows what fascism is anymore other than signifying something bad', time has only proved him more correct. Trump is most certainly not a fascist, he's an ego maniac who will do anything for attention and the easiest group for him to get attention from was the right. To brand him a fascist insinuates he actually has enough forethought to have an ideology rather than a bunch of populist policies cobbled together forming no coherent overall strategy. I'm so bored of hearing this 'Trump is Hitler!' nonsense, if you folks on the left spent as much time coming up with policies and strategies as you do bashing on Trump then the coming election would be a shoe in.

Also do you really believe that the only people who are branded negatively are the ones who deserve it? I've been called a fascist by the left almost as often as I've been called a jew or snowflake by the right. For the record I associate with neither ideology as I think that both groups policies and ideas are based on fantasy and idealism rather than pragmatic problem solving. That being said at least the left cares about people, mostly.

replies.text:
Jean N√©mar Which brand of conservatism are you referring to exactly? Are you referring to the neo-conservatism of Bush? How about the neo-liberalism and family values of Reagan? Maybe you're talking about libertarianism? Perhaps the evangelical religious right that Mike Pence represents? Or are you exclusively referring to the populist conservatism of Trump because that's the type of conservatism that suits your point?

Conservatism in an umbrella term that encompasses many different ideologies and is near meaningless on its own. Similarly the term 'liberal' refers to a wide range of ideologies some of which would actually be considered conservative by modern standards such as classical liberalism. In the modern political climate both terms have been nearly completely devalued and are more often used as an insult, either direct or implied, than they are as a description. Due to this I refuse to talk in terms of liberal vs conservative as it gets in the way productive discussion.

replies.author: @jaceh4942
replies.text:
LOL same. I grew up in a highly religious, young Earth creationist household and by the time I was 14 I was deeply questioning my beliefs. I didn't "become an atheist" but I sort of just realized I was one. 

I eventually stumbled across the atheist/skeptic community on the internet and realized I wasn't alone which was nice. Hearing all these people talk about why they don't believe in various religions was refreshing. I had never heard anyone openly discuss their disbelief. It was so taboo for my family. It was so nice to be out of my Christian bubble. The problem was that I continued to watch these videos after I had already become comfortable with what I believe. The videos were basically preaching to the choir. I already agreed with them so why was I still watching? To reaffirm myself of my newfound beliefs (or lack thereof). I was no longer in my Christian bubble, but I did fall into a whole new bubble and it took me a couple years to realize it. They convince you that all religious people are idiots and are incapable of using logic. They teach you to look down on people who believe in things without evidence. They convince you that religion is evil. Although these things are sometimes true, it is such a black and white way of viewing it.

I still consider myself an atheist because by definition I am one, but I try not to associate with the "new atheist" movement. Most of the time I just tell people I am "non-religious" instead of "atheist" just so they don't associate me with those people.

I just hate how videos like this make mention of strawmen of one side (SJWs, inflated numbers, etc) - and then at the same point, only have one giant strawman of the other side... Slight mischaracterizations, and every now and then allowing for an outright lie (like the Thunderfoot Brexit part of this video - it said "the comment section never brought any arguments about it, but was just reactionary dislikes" - as someone who saw the whole thing go down and went part of a lot of debates in those sections - and yes, providing facts, gonna have to call bullshit, and either a deliberate lie, or someone who just wasn't willing to dig deeper than a couple comments to disprove his point. You can't just outright deny there wasn't any actual discourse, which is bullshit).

Anyway, getting back to the mischarcerizations... The problem of the 'skeptic community', is that it is it's own echo chamber and bubble? Each area of YouTube is within it's own bubble if you don't get outside of those talking points - even this one. yes, conservatives, SJWs, Anti-SJWs should be mindful of the overwhelming power of confirmation bias in the human brain, and how EVERYONE has a tendency to it, regardless on if you want to accept that or not; and it should be people's goals to try and go outside of it, and challenge it (hence, why an Anti-SJW like myself, knew what three arrows was from the past, still went here)

Where are the strawmans you say? That we see a feminist or SJW behind every corner is one; no. The actual point of a lot is more that they are the institutional opinion, from universities censoring wrongthink, to politicians (especially in Europe/England) - even downright going after people for wrongthink, speaking bad about Islam, gays, etc - even if the opinion is mild. Sure 'well, these are small cases, the crazy redhead screaming feminist' - so what if they are, most of us do realize most of them are not that crazy. But we are seeing general trends, and where as a society we need to fight battles that people like you seem to refuse to think are happening and think it is a 'non-existent problem' - despite it showing up many times over again. At political, large corporate, and high academic levels. 

I could go into some of the other strawmen of this video itself, but I feel I have already been ranting for too long, but if you still want me to - just say so.

replies.author: @seanbrodney7716
replies.text:
I mean that's always how it goes tbh.  It's easy to attack a strawman all day long by choosing your targets very selectively: you'll always find a nutjob or two to attack if you go looking no matter the group.  Refuting demands for evidence backed proposals (say, a demand for healthcare backed by, perhaps, evidence that it could be cheaper per American), and actually engaging with that argument to do so, is much harder.  

This is why the Ben Shapiros of the world aren't worth listening to, and it's why it's so important to listen for those verbal tactics for avoiding real engagement with a topic.  It's why it's so important to know exactly what people are criticizing and why, and if that is even a reasonable portrayal of the ideology in question.  If the question "what is an SJW" doesn't even have a clean predictable answer, or that definition shifts with every introduction of new evidence, then criticizing SJW's should make you pretty uncomfortable.  

See I can say: I hate terfs with some confidence because I know exactly what a terf is (a trans exclusionary "radical feminist": a person who identifies as feminist but does not believe trans women qualify as women).  I can make a feminist argument about why this is not consistent with feminism, or a scientific argument about how this is unfounded, or an epistemological argument about the meaning of gender, or honestly I can make a practical argument about how this belief is linked more to fear and hate than reason.  The point is, when the group/belief is well defined, the group/belief can be criticized meaningfully without resorting to verbal tactics.  It's just not possible to make a coherent argument about what is wrong with SJW's because SJW's just don't really exist: The definition of SJW is hazy at best (the borders move constantly), and any definitions typically given don't match up with any legitimately prominent ideologies

I don't even think the data is wrong, just the conclusions certain people get from it. I think IQ tests and crime statistics are poor ways of judging a race, because they're things that can be heavily affected by socioeconomic status. Refusing to take this simple fact into account means that you're married to the idea that race creates a genetic predisposition to violence and lack of intelligence without solid proof, which is racist. Sure if you take the entire country into account it would seem that black people get arrested for (not necessarily commit) more crimes. But try comparing New York with Chicago. replies.author: @ArtofFreeSpeech
replies.text:
@vassilyvodka2638 Which is fine... good for you.  It doesn't happen in Switzerland, perhaps, but it DOES happen here in the USA, and we Americans, for the most part, are pretty serious about our freedom of speech.  Look up the case of James Damore (who simply stated facts and was labeled a bigot who was "anti-diversity" even though he was TRYING to help google attract more women -- and look how the major news outlets reported it), or how the free speech rally in Berkeley was shut down due to violence by the left.  Watch some Karen Straughan on how men are now the oppressed class in the US, and so on (you may not agree with her -- *I* don't agree with everything she says, but she makes some great points).

  Just because these things haven't happened to you in Switzerland, doesn't mean they don't happen to people in other countries.  As I've stated in other posts, being an anti-SJW in the USA has a LOT more to do with freedom of speech and opposing victimhood culture than anything else.  IMO, a country abandoning personal responsibility (that is, widespread blaming of others for your problems) is the beginning of the end of freedom in that country.

replies.author: @daniodude
replies.text: First of all, nice strawman. Secondly, the n word also had negative connotations and was primarily a slur in the past, seen through the "history" that you describe (see: literally any reputable historical journal/article). When you want to describe a concept, it's fine to bring up the controversy surrounding it and explain what it actually means. What's not ok is to improperly identify the problem, ignore the controversy, and justify your actions for the sake of "historical accuracy," all the while not taking responsibility for what you say. Hate speech is labeled as such because it is primarily hateful. An average person wouldn't care about your beliefs, but if you mix the n word into your everyday vocabulary, you're only showing your own ignorance of basic human ethics. Also, what kind of situation would you even use the n word in?

replies.text: Prometheus/Adrian Chase what's funny about the word nigger? EVERY time I've been called that, it wasn't a funny context at all, regardless of how the person tried to frame it afterwards. The word is historically offensive and has a slew of negative racial stereotypes behind it that are generations deep. It's not okay for anyone to throw that word in my face, unless it's totally clear where they're coming from. If you'd like to make a joke using it right now feel free, and if people call you on it it, retaliate or call you a racist bigot for using the word that's fine too.  It's not so much about stopping free speech as holding people accountable for their bullshit, and understanding that some jokes JUST AREN'T FUNNY... If you have any black friends ask them how they feel when they hear that word coming at them as a "joke"... If you don't have any black friends... I wonder why...

replies.author: @stargazer162
replies.text:
@WillKarleskint I liked Rags a bit when I was too deep into the PC master race rabbit hole (I kinda still am, but at least I don't try to evangelize everyone about how amazing PC is compared to consoles). Anyways, I liked him talking about how great PC is and other gaming-related stuff, but I eventually noticed how much of a political agenda his videos had, an agenda which I was starting to believe, influenced by not only him, but by a lot of people I followed for various reasons repeating similar ideas.

Another one was a Japanese guy who had a channel called "Find your love in Japan". I wasn't interested on getting a Japanese girlfriend or anything but I stumbled across his channel and found his content interesting, I liked hearing about his opinions on various topics regarding Japanese culture, but as his channel grew his content slowly transitioned from talking about Japanese culture to very American-influenced far-right topics, for example giving his opinion about black people but only talking about black Americans and his views on BLM. I stopped following him by that time, so I don't know if his channel has changed of if he went full anti-SJW / alt-right, but back then because I liked the guy and enjoyed hearing his opinions, I wasn't very critical about the far-right stuff he said, and often found myself agreeing with it just because it sounded reasonable and I was hearing them from everyone I used to watch, without really thinking too much about the kind of ideas I was starting to believe.

replies.author: @syb2965
replies.text:
Someone on Reddit has conveniently put my thoughts into words:

"I myself am left-wing (centre-left to be precise), but if there is anything I cannot stand in our political climate, it's the sheer amount of hubris and unwarranted self-importance emanating from political illiterates who, now more so than ever, are beginning to gain a foothold in the online discourse not through the merit of legitimate arguments or even attempting to make a point, but through the act of sniping at others who seek legitimate understanding or conversation, condescension and a misplaced sense of elitism."

"Unfortunately, there seems to be a rising tide of this occurring specifically within the left-wing, with pseudo-intellectual hacks like the men behind the Chapo Trap House, hbomberguy and others who, rather than articulating legitimate criticisms against anti-SJWs, instead prefer to misrepresent their ideological opponents and act as if their (often uneducated) opinions are not only righteous, but install a sanctimonious culture of fart-huffing and judgemental bigotry, with a veneer of snark to attempt to mask the fact that they have little of substance to offer the conversation, just further hostility and regression in a time where it is already rampant. They would rather win an argument and confirm their views than actually have their viewpoints challenged and possibly consider adapting them, or even attempt to persuade others with actual reason to their point of view."

"There doesn't really seem to be much criticism directed at this specific group of pseudo-intellectuals besides general anti-SJW talking points, which I think is a cause of concern, given their rise in popularity amongst not only SJWs, but average left-wingers and centrists as well. This proudly vitriolic and unsubstantiated group needs to be isolated from the general image of the progressive left and light needs to be shed on their unjustified arrogance."

author: @lightblueskies
text:
It's so odd how 'SJW' started as a term used in feminists circles (on tumblr) to talk about people that became so radical in their ideas that the definition of feminist simply didn't apply to them anymore (like talking about men as "the enemy"). It was a term used by tumblr feminists to make fun of people that were supposedly part of their online community, but obviously didn't care about improving the world around them and just used feminism as an excuse to be angry at people. 

And then the term 'SJW' started being used to undermine the credibility of the people that founded the term...

replies.author: @FunkyDealers
replies.text:
Honestly, it really wasn't at first though at least how i see it (admittedly this is anecdotal but I have been on tumblr for a long time and ive seen the best and worst of this hellsite)

I first started seeing "sjw" as a sort of uplifting term for feminists who really upheld intersectionality. However around late 2014/2015, id say, that people were catching on to this term and making cringe comps and threads making fun of the loudest, most misguided feminists. Eventually, people really tried to damage control and distance themselves with the term and i think thats when sjw started to just mean "extreme feminist" by force of anti-sjw's creating anti sjw content and said content completely blowing up.

on another note, feminists who would most likely be seen as "sjw's" are actually feminists thatmost likely never even used the term and should absolutely be criticized but for different reasons. For instance "man haters" are usually white feminists and radfems/terfs. An intersectional feminist will talk about the problems in society that hurt men amd all kinds of men: black men, men of color, gay men, trans men, men that dont fall under the upheld stereotype of manly man, men who are casted aside, mental health for men. White feminists will often not understand that you cant just seperate society's problems as a men vs women issue based on gender alone. Black men amd women still face oppression under the axis of being black. And White women do not have the same struggle as a Black woman. Intersectionism is about embracing the axies of power dynamics.
And then we have terfs and radfems, unsurprisingly a lot of them are white. They hate men so much, they see trans women as men and therefor as "invaders". 

This became longer than anticipated, but just to circle this back around, "sjw" actually does have more of a background so i thpught maybe elaborating on that would be helpful. Honestly, talking about this makes me want to do actual digging and research instead of recalling my experience on tumblr.

replies.author: @HozukiHangetsu
replies.text:
@8thMountain Jordan Peterson (for example) ostensibly knows a little bit about a lot of critical theory. Just enough rope to hang himself with. He's got some solid knowledge of Carl Jung and the theory of archetypes (which amounts to what?), but I (being more attuned to Freud, Ferenczi, Abraham & Torok's psychoanalytic principles than Jung's) would never try to out-Jung him, nor would I pretend to have the necessary background or interest to challenge his Jungian points.

Jordan Peterson (and with him, most of the openly anti-Marxist reactionary right) demonstrably does NOT know a lot about Marx, any of the various Marxism(s) (he has either never read him, or misreads him egregiously), poststructuralism, deconstruction, or postmodernism. Bet he's never touched Lyotard or Jameson, or any other theorists concerned primarily with "postmodernism." But he certainly pretends to know something about it--and he lectures on it, and writes books on it as though his opinion is informed. Meanwhile, the average undergrad understands critical theory more thoroughly than he does (PhD, professorship, and all).

Stefan Molyneux is perhaps among the worst of the blatant non/mis-readers. Listening to him talk about Foucault (calling him a Marxist when he rejects Marxism outright, for example) is like listening to the kid who has a presentation on Moby Dick, but has only ever seen cartoon adaptations & references. "OH, there's a big white whale and a guy with a peg leg, and the other guy that goes 'CALL ME ISHMAEL'. And they go and catch the white whale!"

Basically, when they start actually *reading* (like, just in general--why do almost none of these imbeciles actually read anything in its entirety??? It's lazy as hell!) the arguments that they rail against so strongly, *then* and only then will they be taken seriously.

Until then, they're just like the person who assumes that Ahab and the crew caught the whale at the end with his blasphemed, blood-ritualized harpoon, and got home to his lonely wife and kid--that the Pequod made it home, and the crew got filthy rich off of mountains of spermaceti.

replies.author: @basedbattledroid3507
replies.text:
I know right? It's the most annoying thing in the world, YouTube never recommends anything relevant to what I've searched, I am sick to death of the Anti-SJW bollocks. 

Never expressed the slightest bit of interest in it, I frequently say "I'm not interested, I don't like this video" but it recommends twice as many, it's like cutting heads off the bloody Hydra! 


It's like YouTube's algorithms are trying to take the piss or something, I feel like the computer has some sort of anti-human vendetta driving it to make us all suicidal with frustration and depression, because we come on YouTube to watch something funny and let go of tension but then a bunch of "Rekt feminazi destroyed by Jordan Peterson", and without even watching; the thumbnail and title alone sap my faith in humanity. 

We don't have to like each other, just tolerate each other, stop bickering and bitch-fighting, pretty sure most of us 90s kids grew up watching X-Men but didn't take in the positive message hidden beneath the colour. Sorry little rant, but I hope you could get my gist.

We don't have to get all politically correct with each other but the alternative should not be "Become an Arsehole".


What irks me even more is when I had an Uber driver who was all anti-SJW, just the lewdness of everything he was saying, the pure hatred of the world, the paranoia...

...For one thing; as a gay disabled man; I wasn't really all that happy when he said gay people should be put in a death camp (to stop aids from spreading) and that disability was a myth by dole bludgers to scam the government. I would've thought my disability was obvious anyway. 

Then he had the gall to invite me to some Alt-Right meeting he was having in a week's time, like he didn't spend 20 minutes insulting me, that much of a narcissist he just thought that he had "Ben Shapiro'd" and subsequently recruited me.

I also didn't like the attack on my privacy, I remember a time when we had Anonymous Voting because Political leanings were a private, personal matter,  everyone's allowed to have their own and believe what they want, but it should be private and kept to elections.

I dunno, I just hate the priority that this generation assigns to social media, I feel like none of this would've happened if social media was purely used as social media, nearly every site is a bloody platform nowadays. I blame the existence of edgy, new-age politix regarding "SJWs & Alt-Right" entirely on the irresponsible use of social media.

I think we delude ourselves into thinking we're higher along in the evolutionary timeline because we have shiny, swipy screens, we're really just the same angry, anxious apes we were when the wheel came about, but we have better wheels, even I feel like I can't control my anger and fear most of the time. I'm typing this with a broken hand in a splint because I got into an argument with my brother a week ago and put a hole in the wall. I feel like our ambition outgrows our higher reasoning and compassion, it's why we have nuclear bombs and cyberbullying. 

Not saying we don't have good things, I wouldn't have my lovely pet cat if one of my old friends from high school didn't put an ad up for him on Facebook, and some of the stuff is convenient, although I just think the impact of the bad intentions are definitely magnified by the abuse of modern technology. 

Back in the day, if you wanted people to commit suicide; you had to mob them face-to-face and bully them. Nowadays you send it all online and you don't even get the guilty feeling when you look into that person's eye. And I say all this as someone who survived their own suicide attempt, at the age of 8. 

I think it's disturbing enough that an 8 year old knows how to prepare for suicide, but the internet has made suicide even more streamlined than it was when I was a kid. You've got instant online mobs across the world, usually from complete strangers, you've got guided videos on how to use household objects for suicide, it's sickening really.

I just think we have to appreciate the magnitude of the phones in our palms; they are like nuclear bombs really, and we have to start treating people the way we want to be treated again; just understand the grasp of basic compassion and "if you don't like it; don't do it to them", it shouldn't be hard but the idea seems lost on some people. 

I mean, maybe I'm overreacting and the world isn't going to shit, maybe YouTube just bombarded me with horrific content against my will and it's left that impression on me and it's my fault and I should cheer up, and I would be incredibly happy if that were the case. Either way; I think it'd be beneficialtfor most of us to put the phone down once in a while

author: @fionna9891
text:
Also, I'd like to add that the term "SJW" is basically propaganda. While radical feminists exist (I'd rather we started calling them TERFs and misandrists, their views are definitelly not just feminism but more extreme), regular feminism is mostly just having a critical point of view on how our culture views gender roles.

What these content creators like to do is cherry pick people's takes and act like everyone believes them and that it's a monolith. That's what the concept of an "SJW" is, it's this fictional idea of what the feminist movement is like.

If you all want to see what a lot of feminists actually believe, I think reading through some r/AskFeminists threads could be a good start. Maybe even make a post if you want to.

replies.author: @KlausBahnhof
replies.text:
@padowo  Maya Forstater got into trouble by pointing out the fact that nobody can change their biological sex. Apparently this statement is controversial to some people. She said some other things about not believing in self-identification. I agree with Rowling here: nobody should lose their job over such a common scepticism regarding self-identification. The overreaction to their views was a truly dismal affair, and the numerous rape/death threats made the activists look like dangerous lunatics.
I was pointing out that sex categories are important because they are the basis for women's rights in society. Women's services, sports, shelters, prisons, etc. are all defined by the sex category of female. If this basis can be altered to include biological males, then the idea of women's sex-based rights simply disappears.
Yes, very few people are denying the existence of sex categories, but many people are elevating the social phenomenon of gender to a much higher status than that of sex. This is what I disagree with. Gender is essentially irrelevant, whilst sex is important (hopefully I don't have to elaborate on this).
I don't agree that gender-critical people are hateful towards trans-people. They just don't subscribe to the idea that a person can change their sex. Someone can be supportive of trans-people and also reject gender ideology, the two are not mutually exclusive.

replies.author: @agilemind6241
replies.text:
The problem here is with the definition of TERF. TERF started out as a specific ideology that isn't by requirement trans-phobic but is extremely appealing to transphobes, so the ideology attracted trans-phobic feminists which muddied its ideology with transphobia. Somewhere along the line, it has gotten muddied further and is now applied basically to all women who are transphobes (regardless of if they are feminists or not) as well as to man-hating feminists (regardless of if they are transphobic or not), so has been morphed into a catch-all term for "bad women I can feel good about mocking" and now half the time it is just as much a straw-man term as SJW is. 

It's honestly at the point that when people shout insults about TERFs I have no idea who or what they are actually talking about, which defeats the purpose on language in the first place. It really is no different from the anti-SJW rabbit-hole as far as I can see : people wanting to feel good about themselves by derisively mocking their imaginary concept of [buzzword] group. And it will be no more beneficial to democratic debate and civil society as the anti-SJW crowd.

By all means criticize transphobes - whether they are feminists or not - but be clear and specific in your criticisms. Sticking your tongue out or giving someone a virtual middle finger does nothing productive.

If you have no idea who people are talking about when they insult them it sounds more like an issue with you considering how absolutely virulent it is in the UK.

If you disagree that "Trans Exclusionary Radical Feminists" must be transphobic then you should probably present an example of the things non-transphobic TERFs would believe.

replies.author: @KlausBahnhof
replies.text:
@fionna9891 "The Left" broadly encapsulates a selection of cultural/ideological values, giving a simplistic yet still valuable insight into attitudes within society. It's not a useless term, although it is used so loosely that it has lost some relevance (like the word "bigot").
I care about traditional left-wing values (like environmentalism and economic equality). I don't really give a shit about identity issues because of their strictly anthropocentric nature. Certain people might consider that "bigoted", but I don't really give a shit about their opinion either.
That doesn't mean I wish any harm on trans people. I generally feel bad for them because the activists who claim to represent them arguably do more harm than good.
It is the extremist activists of all flavours who are causing disunity. Threats of violence or rape towards radical feminists is a good example of this.

replies.text:
@icyplatinum3687 I don't wish to revisit this thread since most of the replies were made by people who ignored half of what I said, but I'll reply to you.

First, your claim that biological sex is "mostly hormones" is simplistic to the point of absurdity. Males and females have distinctly different bodies (for obvious reasons relating to the evolution and reproduction of our species). If a one million year old human skeleton is found, biologists can determine the sex of the fossil. There is more to sex than simply hormones. Also, you put biological sex in quotation marks, which suggests that you don't believe it is a real thing. This type of thinking is deeply troubling for those of us in the reality-based community. There is no such thing as birth sex, or assigned gender either.

Second, I didn't mention women's bathrooms.

Third, I've heard your other arguments dozens of times and I still don't think they are based in any logic or evidence. Claiming that trans people face more risk of violence (whether that is true or not, as no evidence is ever provided) does not give you the right to put females *in female-only spaces* at risk. You also completely disregard the wishes of females who seek shelter *in order to be away from males.* Forcing them to accept males into their vulnerable spaces is regressive and fundamentally sexist.

You said "The risk for cis women doesn't increase from trans women in their spaces" so here are some examples to dispute that (copied from a friend's comment):

Look up Karen White, a rapist on the street who is housed with women and raping women in prison. Look up "Princess Zoee Marie Andromeda Love," formerly known as Hobby Bingham, who raped a 12-year old girl, and later was transferred to a women‚Äôs prison, where he raped a developmentally delayed survivor of sexual abuse who was forced to share a cell with him.

Why do you (and other commenters here) choose to ignore these events, and countless others like them?
I think the answer lies in the fact that gender ideology *demands* that they be ignored.

replies.text:
Just a little note to everyone on all sides: don't spout strong opinions about things you don't understand.

If you're sure YOUR belief is absolutely right, then it probably isn't.

Please learn the difference between facts and opinions.
And then, make your decisions based on facts, not opinion. 

The problem isn't so much people on the Right or the Left. The problem is extremism. People dive into this whole us-versus-them nonsense on ALL sides. The entire idea of "sides" is itself a problem. Stop trying to "win" or make someone else "lose". How about maybe you "learn"?

/End pointless rambling

Love to you all.

replies.author: @petitpois23
replies.text:
The Worst Catholic ill agree with you that the wage gap is a tricky subject to defend, and not everything they say about it is true (i would argue that the wage gap only starts applying itself heavily after a woman has a baby, other than that it may be based on worker performance or a corrupt manager's gender bias). and that discussions about rape culture are often brought to extremes (i'm not trying to be "that person" but i seriously do feel threatened when strange men are around me, just because of how i was raised to think all men are predators). honestly you're more likely to find a nickel on the ground than you are to be jumped while walking home and raped (most rapists are people the victim knows). but it can happen and it sucks and it scares us. the fact that some people will shun women for dressing skimpy and blame the victim for looking like a slut is abhorrent.

and maybe women aren't exactly "oppressed" as some would have you believe but there are certain societal standards that women are expected to uphold at least to some degree (like dressing nice, having a decent body shape, being modest, taking care of their hygiene on a daily basis), most of these things that men don't have or are more acceptable when a man does it (and when i say those things, im refering to individuals who find it hard to do those things, like the physically disabled or mentally ill). the times are changing, though, so i believe that one day this may be old news.

but you also have the pink tax, which is the tax on feminine products and other products marketed towards women. some people deny its existence, but this is where unfairness starts, because women have to pay more for the same things that are marketed for men, for essentially the same purpose. and its not like they do different things either, except maybe they smell different. they don't have any reason to put a tax on stuff like that. and for feminine products, we already have to buy things that are necessary to care for a natural bodily function, which is unfair for women in poverty who have to choose between using their paycheck on food or tampons. its almost like being punished for existing.

yikes when did this turn into an essay lmao. but im not saying the opposition has any merit but the feminists who don't scream at the top of their lungs do have a point. we just have to be loud enough to drown out the crazies

@jpc1918-h4k In response to "Merkel is center right. She's left wing politically and that's clear as day to anyone we with half a brain. If thats center right how fucking far has the Overton window gone to the far left?"

- I am from Germany and YES Merkel is absolutly considered center-right here (being more on the neo-liberal side of things).
- If you're not German, maybe don't conflate the German center-right with other countrys center-right?
- Merkel would be probably considered pretty far left wing in the USA for example (she is pro-universal-healthcare, helped refugees, pro-guncontrol, pro-abortion, pro-social-safetynet).


- It frustrates me when e.g. Americans bring up my country without understanding that it's not 1/1 comparable to their system.
- An example: when Americans complain about far-right partys being considered "extreme" here - in Germany we've got a different definition of that word so everything anti-democratic is 'politically extreme' by default (neo-nazis, socialists, radical islamists).

I first got into Contrapoints with her video on Jordan Peterson, which is superb and is still one of the best videos discrediting that dull, shallow grifter. I went ahead and watched a bunch of her other videos that were generally irreverent, thoughtful and empathetic, even to unsympathetic demographics like incels. It was right around that time she came out as trans, and ever since then the content has descended into a nasty, narcissistic validation of her own identity, which people gush and fawn over. There's zero worthwhile discussion in the comments under the videos and any hint of criticism is jumped upon with the usual arrogant, self-satisfied claims of bigotry etc.
Contrapoints is now the personification of an SJW hell-hole, with some of the best production values on YouTube.

author: @iliakatster
text:
I feel like a lot of right wing viewpoints come from wanting things to be simple. 

The older republicans want to go back to the 1950's when everyone had a job, and a nice house (and you could easily ignore all the black people getting redlined)  and you watched some TV with your family after dinner together, and there was no racial guilt or divisions.

 The young people want to go back to their childhood where race just didn't exist, where you could play videogames and not think about how divisive the "Allah akbar" terrorists and the women you won as prizes for winning the game were, and you didn't have to think about "actual terrorists" since they were no longer attacking and were defeated long ago, and the lone wolf not-terrorists weren't shooting up schools yet, and of course racism was just an imaginary fairy that would go away if everyone just STOPPED TALKING ABOUT IT.

replies.author: @dkroll92
replies.text:
@domgaar9933 you just had to be a white guy. At the time that was the second largest demographic behind white women, at a large margin compared to today. The problem wasn't tyranny of the minority, it was tyranny of the majority.

We we're dealing with NOW is the threat of tyranny by a minority (or rather, plurality), as America becomes more diverse by the numbers and whites (who traditionally support right-wing ideas) cease to be the big fish in the pond. That's why conservatives are so on about so-called election integrity laws - the easiest way for them to compete in the democratic process is by arbitrarily limiting turnout from demographics that, for whatever reasons, don't vote for right-wing politicians

author: @liavas1640
text:
I'd like to thank Hbomberguy and Contrapoints for helping me out of the reactionary right rabbit hole a few years ago, but what actually kickstarted my exit before that was anti-SJW incompetency itself.

I was watching an Atheism Is Unstoppable video (yes, cringe), not thinking about it too hard, and was jolted back to reality when I heard him say "black people have lower IQs." He was citing a study that thanks to my current statistics background I understand is wrong on other levels, but at the time it felt wrong purely because of how racist it sounded. Sometime later I was watching another video of his where he was criticizing The Young Turks, and the way he was talking about the female host got weirdly sexually degrading. By the time I'd started getting into Blaire White instead I realized how much of a "Pick-Me- I'm-Not-Like-Other-Trans" she could be and I'd finally had enough. Found Contrapoints through Theryn Meyer and it felt like a breath of fresh air.

I have some criticism of this video. (reposting)

5:28 You admit to naming only a few of Carl Benjamin's (Sargon of Akkad) opinions and sure enough, your selection bias is unmistakable. You have mentioned only those opinions that are relevant to your narrative, all the while neglecting to mention Carl's left-wing views such as his opposition to the freedom of association (the libertarian cake question) and his openness to government surveillance of a person's social media and private life. Carl is also self-avowedly pro-choice on the issue of abortion and has advocated on behalf of the concept of the welfare state on numerous occasions.

10:28 The Wall Street Journal is the same outlet that ran a story making an out-of-context connection between PewDiePie and anti-semitism. replies.text:
The term ‚ÄúSJW‚Äù may be overused but it has validity. SJWs are the ones who shut down a school with protests because a conservative is scheduled to speak. SJWs demand teachers get fired for saying that the school doesnt need to tell students what they can dress up as on Halloween. SJWs conflate deferring to science on gender with supporting violence against trans people. 
SJW is a term that designates a real phenomena: hysterical, illogical, self righteous and extremely hostile leftists who have a tenuous grasp of reality, a strong sense of moral superiority, and a nastiness of psyche which compels them to label people who dont share their ideological fanaticism as bigots of various types.

@Clement Washington: By definition, a person advocating to restrict others speech is NOT a defender of free speech. Theres a gray area in what kind of speech counts as harmful and at what point we set the legal limits. These have to be looked at on case by case basis. Defenders of free speech usually prefer to err on the side of too much freedom rather than of too much censorship.

You say Sargon tried to shut down social justice courses? Could you prove that with external sources? Are you sure he tried to shut them down or does the just critisize them for their flaws?

There are definitely people who have a bias against Islam. Some of these are just bigoted people who dislike anything thats different from them. But theres also a real connection between violence and extreme Islamic beliefs. An SJW minded person would call me a bigot because i recognize that connection, even though i have nothing against Islam, as a whole. The reactionary attitude behind SJWism is not limited to the left, but the term caught on because of how trendy the leftist hysteria and vitriol become over issues such as gender, islam, patriarchy, toxic masculinity, white privilege, cultural appropriation, and of the dumbest and most laughable of all the SJW crusades, trigger warnings and safe spaces lol 

SJWs tend to be young people who are utterly spoiled with the privileges of living in an advanced, democratic society, but who buy into and become rabid advocates of every wild critique they encounter about how that society is evil and oppressive. Imagine bemoaning the evils of capitalism on your new laptop while sipping a latte from Starbucks, lmao.

replies.text:
Kurt Barryman 

The White Race (like every other race) does not genetically exist. There is no objective genetic evidence for the race structure that we have today. What the white race is is a collection of different ethnic groups loosely tied by being ‚Äúfrom‚Äù the same continent, even though people have moved in and out of that continent for millennia.

All of the advancements you tie to ‚Äúwhite‚Äù people are the result of two things: Mediterranean Civilization and Euro-Christian imperialism.

Mediterranean civilization includes the Greeks, Italians (Romans etc.), Persians Egyptians, Phoenicians, Islamic Caliphates, Iberians(Spain + Portugal), Turks, Mesopotamians and North Africans.

The Mediterranean was the birthplace of ‚ÄúWestern Culture‚Äù. The peoples of Southern Europe are more genetically related to other Mediterraneans than they are to other northern European groups (such as the Celts, Germanics, and Nordic peoples).

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greeks#Genetics

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haplogroup_J-M172

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haplogroup_E-V68

Northern European groups didn‚Äôt advance past Bronze Age tribal society until the Romans invaded northward, bringing Mediterranean (‚Äúwestern‚Äù) civilization to the far reaches of Europe.

That‚Äôs when the Euro-Christian identity spread across the land and the idea of a ‚Äúwhite‚Äù race began to form. Then came the imperialist era which was then quickly followed by the Industrial era (started in England, spread out over the rest of Europe quickly afterwards). They literally just got lucky. That‚Äôs what allowed for the creation of the colonialism and imperialism of the rest of the world, not ‚Äúsuperior white genetics‚Äù.

Your ideology and worldview is predicated on historical ignorance, xenophobia, bigotry and sociopathy.

That‚Äôs why educated left-leaning people see you as malevolent idiots.

replies.author: @galoobigboi
@StrawberryCosmonaut
replies.text:
If you're getting bored of this I'll add to this once again. I was originally addressing my opinion pretty generally, and I assumed the defensive when you replied back with a blunt reply. Which obviously you're allowed to do and in hindsight, it really wasn't that bad, I suppose I can be guilty of reacting strongly too. The point in which I disagree with being labelled an SJW is that I support your freedom of speech and expression, hence why I never said you shouldn't be able to do that, just that it's always an annoyance to me when I see people attacking each other instead of trying to have civilised discussions about the subject, you could disagree with me on every fundamental level and that's absolutely fine, but if you do so in an aggressive way or resort to personal attacks I find it negates the purpose of the debate and really- nobody ever changes somebody's mind by being aggressive.

Still though you're entitled to do that, maybe I should of clarified that more before, and for the record I am biased to my side so you are right on that, but as far as I can consciously tell I'm perfectly happy to look at your perspective and your side of the argument, but I can't make other people do the same, I don't think being on my side of the fence makes me a superior person by the way, and I do believe empathy is needed as most friendships and meaningful connections that help us through the confusing mess of life are connections with empathy, but if you mean in an internet context then fair enough.

And it is all subjective man you're right, there's nothing wrong with the things you're saying, I was just stating how annoyed I was at the way in which people always end up arguing online, I'm not claiming to be all in the right though as looking back I can already see some flaws in a couple of the things I was stating likewise with some of your comments, like we say it is all subjective.

Much love and snowflaky hugs my dude :D

replies.text: I would recommend people like Rachel Oates, comic skeptic, telltale, and Mr. Athiest! I feel like a big reason why a lot of us became atheists, to begin with, is because we didn't want to be hateful and we saw the fearmongering,  oppression, and superiority complex ideology that was being pushed (often covertly) by our religions. It makes no sense for internet atheist communities to thrive off of those very same things, just re-branded. I wanted something BETTER with atheism... not the same shit in a different pile. And then often these Athiest communities strongly discourage questioning anything that is said by their idolized creators or any of their approved set of ideas so it's like escaping one religion/cult and just landing in another one. The only difference is that instead of worshipping a god they expect you to worship this unrealistic ideal of "Classical" western society... andd if you know much about ancient Greece/Rome you'd realize that you'd rather stay in 2019.

author: @xandermin
text:
I found the whole anti-SJW community through Tumblr. The first anti-SJW video I saw was a shoeonhead video, & through her I started watching Armored Skeptic & a few Sargon videos. It was way back in 2014, right as gamergate was catching steam. I think that's when anti-SJW youtube really took off. Those blogs & youtubers are what introduced me to politics, & I started doing my own research. I read a bunch of second-hand university books on political science & sociology, & the more I learned from those objective sources, the more I realized that the anti-SJW crew were all a bunch of hacks who didn't know what they were talking about. They don't understand the basics of the political ideologies they talk about, they don't know political history, they just assume that they're right. 

In a weird way, it's the anti-SJW's fault that I'm getting a bachelor's in political science because they were what got me interested in the topic in the first place.

Even all that time watching anti-SJWs I still felt rather uncomfortable if I were to watch a Lauren Southern video. I stopped watching andywarski when he became sympathetic to alt-right people and their opinions, that was like a slap in the face of, "what the fuck am I watching?"

replies.author: @shearonimo
replies.text:
Everyone fell into it, because SJWs entered the mainstream consciousness around like 2013/2014, and it was incredibly easy to make fun of them no matter what. Also, the right wing didn't exactly have any similar, new  punching-bag representations until around the Trump campaign. It's really hard for me to explain, but what I'm trying to say is that it was really, *really* easy to make fun of SJWs, and even lefties did it too. However, the far-right were the only people who catered to it, and used it to their advantage.

In 2014 for me, there was no better laugh as a teenager than seeing a dumb SJW get put in their place, or look like a fool. The far right served me more of that, and turned it slowly into anger by saying that the SJWs weren't just stupid, but a PROBLEM FACING THE WORLD. And then from there, even if I wasn't laughing, I was still drawn to it. And then I was in there until I saw a few contrapoints videos, and started watching Lindsay Ellis again. And I got out.
