replies.author: @ernststravoblofeld
replies.text: Maximilien Robespierre    I think you really have something there. Being old, I have a rather surprising example of this from before YouTube.  In the earliest days of Rush Limbaugh's radio show, he was playing a part, a caricature of a far right pundit, much like The Colbert Report. I don't really know what his real political beliefs were at the time, but he played the part in a very entertaining way. But he went on a speaking tour, and for the first time, he saw how seriously his fans took the show, and that changed him. From that point on, the comedy fell away and the outrage took center stage. The quality of the show dropped, and the listenership boomed. He may or may not have had right wing views before, but at that point, he embraced the crazy and ran with it, heading towards the conspiracy minded far right.  The interaction between method acting and fan feedback, can really change a person.

replies.author: @elizabethwear4113
replies.text:
@matty

The big problem around race in America is just the fact that it has such a long, severe, and recent history, that it's nearly impossible to extract it from the conversation. And I know this is a common argument that people like to wave away but it's one that's legitimately worth exploring. There are black Americans in my generation whose parents or grandparents were not allowed to attend white schools or buy houses in white neighborhoods, and in a lot of ways some of our institutions haven't compensated adequately for the shift in attitudes around race that has happened since. It really wasn't that long ago that there was a *very* strict implicit racial caste system which had been built for centuries, and unfortunately it'll probably take more than just a generation or two to disentangle ourselves from the cultural and systemic remnants of that. It doesn't help that white nationalism has been increasing in the mainstream here- and it was a little bit popular to begin with- which only further necessitates a near-obsessive analysis of society's treatment of race by all parties. Race is just one of those things I think most of us would *like* to be able to move past but there's just too much work left to be done, and so yeah, the reputation is probably well-founded.

Policing video games for "sexist" material is almost as absurd as policing pornos for "sexist" material. The whole concept is absurd and then she gives off a sense of unarguably being right with smirky arrogance. If it was a different person doing the videos, I'm sure it would still get some backlash, but it would never have been so popular to criticize the videos compared to Sarkeesian herself. You can make the case that policing (especially joke policing) any entertainment or artistic content, however, would result in a mountain of backlash from any group of people especially when people saw it hypocritical that Sarkeesian herself never played video games before her fundraising for her project. replies.text:
Much like people that only talk about conspiracy, there comes a time where you run out of shit to talk about and just go nuts. Personally I think the monetary gain youtube provides encourages this a lot more than normal discourse, but it's not the only thing.

I've been in the middle for a while, not the  "skeptic" centrist middle, but I find myself on one site arguing about  the freedom of an artist to draw ugly women and on another site defending men that only draw bimbos.  Both of these segments argue for free expression yet both of them also argue the other is an attack on them as a person. 

In the end I still lean more towards 'Anti-sjws' because how I express myself is more accepted in their circles, but I still hate a lot of it.

replies.author: @cinnanyan
replies.text: If you look into the original meaning and understanding of postmodernism, this anti-SJW stuff is just more postmodernism. Listen for every time they talk about "the narrative", point out some flaws in "the narrative", and use those flaws to claim "the narrative" is invalid in entirety. Throwing away a flawed but mostly correct narrative for a strange and untested one can cause otherwise very rational people to believe bizarre things, whether it's "we need to keep track of everyone's pronouns in our phones or else we'll cause trauma" or "Jews are tricking white women into getting abortions so they can bring in foreign labour". If I ever had the chance to talk to Dave Rubin or Sargon or someone like them, this is the one thing I'd like to point out to them the most.

replies.text: It's marketing and plausible deniability. He wants to attract centrists, liberals (in the American sense of the word), and progressives to his content without setting off alarm bells for reactionary propaganda. The more common way these people operate is by marketing themselves as "centrists" and "moderates" when in reality their views are anything but centrist or moderate. Once upon a time, Carl could pass himself off as center-left, like when he talked about how privatization hurts the poor and hung out with Kyle Kulinski, but after joining UKIP and referring to Steve Bannon as "the little guy", he no longer has anywhere to hide.

replies.author: @GrahamMilkdrop
replies.text:
I think it is ironic that while a person is free to choose their gender identity and simple binary framing of that particular characteristic has long since been rejected, responsibility for defining political identity has been wrestled away from the individual and placed in the hands of groups of 'activists' who claim they support self-determination yet have reduced the political spectrum to a binary model of 'victim' vs 'Fascist' and have no respect whatsoever for nuance or diversity... Even more ironic is that these 'activists' have made endlessly discussing the labelling of celebrity social commentators their sole political activity!


Personally I think that political identity has much greater scope for complex definition than any other identifying aspect of an individual and that if nothing else, a person should be free to self identify and to have their choice respected...  If for no other reason than with the identity issue out of the way we could all move on and discuss issues... debate policy... you know..? Politics stuff. 

All you have to do is not use the N word... or the F word... unless invited to do so. Remember though... political identity is fluid and can change at any time. If someone chooses to identify as a Nazi or a Fascist then that's fine... but it doesn't follow that they are will necessarily be a Nazi or Fascist the next time you meet.   Take someones stated preference for political identity label as the one you adopt when discussing them. It's basic politeness that costs you nothing and ensures that everyone feels respected. 

Think of what we could achieve if we moved forwards together!

Perhaps we could discuss the global economic dependence on the military industrial complex and brainstorm some possible alternative economic models that are fit for the 21st century and beyond... we could explore whether the label 'working class' has any relevance since automation and globalisation decimated the employment market... We might come up with alternatives to large scale industrial manufacturing and its associated employment opportunities... you know..? Like... important stuff. (Plus it is about time we finally ended gender inequality and that pesky pay-gap issue... by making all women CEOs of large corporations as is their basic right...)

replies.author: @minty-s5z6g
replies.text:
@imaratspal Seizure of private property for the good of the people and massive government intervention in the economy in order to ensure mass employment.
Look, it's a bit difficult to discuss the entire development of the Nazi party in a youtube post. Essentially, they started out with both a right and a left wing in their party. The thing is, all the Nazis wanted initially was a strong state with a strong leader who didn't need to listen to parliament but could rather quickly and decisively help his people. Now, they defined his people as Aryan Germans, so following from that would be the disenfranchisement of the Jews and many others (initially not their extinction).

An ideology like this (strong state, strong leader, no parliament of note) isn't exclusively right-wing. It can also attract left-wingers. And it did. But after Hitler's rise to power he eliminated the left-wing of his party. In 1934, there was the Knight of Knives where the Nazis loyal to Hitler killed all the Nazis loyal to Strasser, leads of the left-wing of the Nazi party. After that, the Nazis were decidedly right.wing in ideology (though in practice they kept seizing private property and interfering in the economy). This is why many people don't know about the left-wing of the Nazi party.

Now, their worst crimes, the reason everyone hates them, were right-wing, yes. But what I wanted to highlight wasn't where they ended, but rather where they started, because in order to stop something like this from happening again, we have to stop it when it begins, not when it ends. And it began as a movement with followers from the right and the left. Basically, anyone who's anti-democratic can spiral down into Nazi territory. And there's anti-democratic people on the right and on the left.

REJECTION OF MARXISM

Such a conception of life makes Fascism the resolute negation of the doctrine underlying so-called scientific and Marxian socialism, the doctrine of historic materialism which would explain the history of mankind in terms of the class struggle and by changes in the processes and instruments of production, to the exclusion of all else.

That the vicissitudes of economic life - discoveries of raw materials, new technical processes, and scientific inventions - have their importance, no one denies; but that they suffice to explain human history to the exclusion of other factors is absurd. Fascism believes now and always in sanctity and heroism, that is to say in acts in which no economic motive - remote or immediate - is at work.

author: @fotnite_
text:
I used to be alt-right, would regularly brows through /pol/, but then I befriended a socialist in a class I had, and sometimes we would debate politics. She was much better informed than how influencers I knew would depict socialists and feminists, so I started seeking out left-wing sources to look at. Even before I left the right, I had watched some of Philosophy Tube's videos, and later On Tom Nicholas. Them and other channels helped demonstrate a different mode of thinking, one relying on understanding studies and data, on holding every position based on deeper principles rather than holding many positions as "inherent truths".

This is perhaps a much more positive spin than I normally give to my political journey, but I wanted to emphasize how important intellectual honesty is, and that changing people is possible. That socialist I mentioned earlier knew I was alt-right, but she still treated me with respect like everyone else, and she wasn't arrogant when criticizing my ideas. I know it doesn't work on everyone, and especially not on the internet, but I wouldn't shut out someone, even if they have abhorrent opinions, because change is possible.

author: @El-bq9rk
text:
That exact thing happened to me. I‚Äôm rather young (16) but was even younger (around 14-15) when I stumbled upon these kinda of videos.

 As a young impressionable child/teen I immediately got a sort of feeling of trust and rationality from adults talking calmly and not screaming and screeching like the supposed ‚Äúsjws‚Äù. 

But the deeper I got into the anti sjw videos the more I started seeing stuff I disagreed with. There were still people rationally talking about topics (so I felt inclined to believe) but these included stuff like men being greatly superior to women, homophobia, racism and other extreme beliefs. I am a girl myself and I kinda started feeling like the idea of ‚Äúwomen are weaker, dumber and basically subordinate to men but heyyy you still deserve some basic human rights!!‚Äù was fed to me. 

It stared to kinda impact my self esteem and worth but it was what helped me to realize how extreme they were. 

Slowly but surely i then completely realized how I ended up in the extreme right that was just as, if not more toxic than the extreme left. 
After that I decided to get more onto the middle ground of politics. You shouldn‚Äôt get sucked in too much by either side. Both have good arguments and view points but both can get incredibly toxic and extreme.

author: @thespanishinquisition8628
text:
Oh wow, this video hit really close to home.

What you said in the beginning about people who are a bit center-left (with limited knowledge in politics mind you) seeing these skeptic videos pop up all of a sudden and being dragged into this alt-right propaganda machine is pretty much exactly what happened to me. The only difference being that I also got pulled in by youtubers with scientific backgrounds (like Thunderf00t) who suddenly started making this anti-SJW content. People like Ben Shapiro also seemed really appealing to me at the time with his rapid-fire misinterpretation of facts in all his debates which always seemed to stump his opponents. The only thing that I always disliked (even though I liked their other stances) about people like Shapiro and JBP was their weird stances on LGBTQ issues, gender equality and their faith in the so called 'judeo-christian values' and religion as a whole.  

After falling deeper and deeper down that rabbit hole for a year and a half, I fortunately got back up and faced reality when I saw all these people defending Trump with his dog whistle politics, science denial and those weird conspiracy theories of his. I also started getting curious and watched many of Destiny's debate videos which just showed how stupid and uneducated many of my previous 'idols' (yikes) actually were. 

The dangerous thing with the anti-SJW community is how simplistic and surface-level their arguments are. This means that they can reel in people who don't know anything about politics just by showing the 'other side' being irrational and then make some 'muh free speech' arguments which on the surface seem really appealing to a person who doesn't really know what to think. Most people won't question what they say, nor hear what the other side has to say or if any of the sides align with the facts at all. It's basically 'first come, first served' with the anti-SJW's being the first to come most of the time. 

Anyway, this was a long story/rant. I hope it was somewhat comprehensible.

We need more channels like this one, who can reel people in before the anti-SJW community does. Thank you Three Arrows! And keep up the good work!

replies.text:

replies.author: @3112-x9r
replies.text:
Three Arrows,
I have some criticism of this video.

5:28 You admit to naming only a few of Carl Benjamin's (Sargon of Akkad) opinions and sure enough, your selection bias is unmistakable. You have mentioned only those opinions that are relevant to your narrative, all the while neglecting to mention Carl's left-wing views such as his opposition to the freedom of association (the libertarian cake question) and his openness to government surveillance of a person's social media and private life. Carl is also self-avowedly pro-choice on the issue of abortion and has advocated on behalf of the concept of the welfare state on numerous occasions. 

6:38 Citation needed. You claim that "para-social relationships" are more potent via YouTube than regular television. Please provide sourcing.

7:05 Citation needed. It is unclear to me how watching "Anti-SJW" videos causes a viewer to become part of a "hive mind." Please provide sourcing.

8:52 This is a reflection of the feminist 'male tears' trope back upon feminists and like-minded ID-pol pushers. There is also nothing intellectually dishonest about basking in the schadenfreude towards people who hold opposing viewpoints, even though it may be devoid of reasoning or discussion of policy. Shock value and trolling are common art forms.

9:00 Support of Brexit does not necessarily imply "Anti-SJW dogma." Not only is it possible for an SJW like Louise Mensch to support Brexit, there are arguments in support of Brexit that do not relate to SJW's.

10:28 The Wall Street Journal is the same outlet that ran a story making an out-of-context connection between PewDiePie and anti-semitism. Your logical fallacy is the appeal to authority - a more established media outlet is still capable of producing fake news. It is possible for a YouTuber to offer greater perspective.

10:53 The ‚Äútruly worrisome‚Äù standard you invoke for political developments appears to be based on your personal opinion and is therefore subjective in nature.

11:53 That DNC candidate (Sally Boynton Brown) you mentioned was cheered by the audience and applauded by the other stage-members for her diatribe. This is an example of radicalization of one‚Äôs own base in real time.

replies.author: @qwertyuiopaaaaaaa7
replies.text:
Disheveled Man 
I'm not saying "no people who self identify as politically left-leaning commit acts of violence", I'm saying "most of all people are just regular non-violent people who would like to think of themselves as kind and the hero of their own story." I've met a lot of democrats and republicans, the only ones who were unkind were the ones who dehumanized others by assuming in/out groupings. "Those Trump supporters are nazis" "those liberals are violent mobs". Both of those sentiments can only be subjectively true if you ignore that people are dynamic and can't be grouped into simple villains and heroes.

And I don't live with a "few leftists", I live among a few million. You pick anyone out of the crowd here (left-leaning or not) and their likely going to be a reasonably nice person.

replies.author: @qwertyuiopaaaaaaa7
replies.text:
Disheveled Man 
Yeah, so what? It's still not nice to hurt people's feelings. It's rude and unkind. Societies work better when people are nice to each other, that includes not insulting them. That's why your parents tell you not to be mean. That's why your grandma tells you not to be mean. That's why your elementary school teacher tells you not to be mean.

And if you're not convinced that being nice is the right thing to do, consider that hurting someone's feelings makes them less likely to trust you and listen to your ideas. If you ever want to convince others, change minds, and get power, you will be well served by using kindness to your advantage. So, yeah, don't use the word "faggot" when you can otherwise avoid it. People won't like you and the only person who will suffer is yourself. No one has ever made more friends by using derogatory slurs.

- People protesting peacefully (and mildly inconveniencing a bunch of people sitting in their cars) to petition the public for a redress of grievances

- _Some_ reckless drivers who are plowing through a chain of people, risking to injure these people

replies.author: @MeetDannyWilson
replies.text:
Disheveled Man I watched the video. The SUV was driving throw a chain of people simply standing on the road. I have no problem with someone calling this "plowing" or even "running", because that is what it is, the truth - if you were on the other side, and someone "drove slowly" towards you with their SUV, apparently ready to drive over you if necessary, would you then say "my bad"? Would you also criticize people who complain about the driver of the SUV, saying "no, this is my fault"?

The SUV driver recklessly endangered the lives and bodily integrity of people participating in civil protest. Whatever laws the protesters broke or didn't break with their civil protest, the SUV driver had *NO RIGHT WHATSOEVER* to endanger the lives of the protesters.

Fine, let the state punish the protesters for their civil protest - but the punishment is not up to the SUV driver, the punishment is not to endanger the protesters, and if you turn a blind eye to the SUV driver, dismissing his behavior, then you are taking sides with the worst of the worst of the world. You may not see yourself as rightwinger, I don't know, but you behave exactly as one, condemning civil protesters.

replies.author: @DevinMacGregor
replies.text: I am super on the Left.  8Value has me as a Libertarian Socialist and Political Compass has me as a Left libertarian.  I used to hang out in very volatile spaces and got tired of it so decided to hang out on what I thought was solely on my liberal side. I was like fuck what happened.  I remember seeing an Anita video on my recommended so I clicked on it and got pissed off how oversimplified she made somethings while completely ignoring other things but then I noticed in my feed this Anita sucks video so clicked on that.   This lead me to Sargon and the Sargonites.  When it got to Brexit I started to smell something wrong.  I do not tell people in other countries who to vote for in their own country. I do not know enough for that.  When they embraced Trump I just saw them jumping the shark.  I knew who Donald Trump was since the 1980s and he has always been a joke, shyster, shady fuck.  So they went from being skeptics to ideologues.  I just stopped watching all those channels.

replies.text: I think shit got more insane from the SJW side and so a lot of people just threw up their hands and went "fuck it."

replies.author: @DevinMacGregor
replies.text:
I just want to point out that Anita has had constructive criticism aimed at her, it is just that she blows off all forms of it. I have read it on her videos before she shut all comments down. I think the Sargoniauts just took it way too far.  Defenders of Anita though will be quick to point out that she is only looking at it from a feminist perspective BUT that is where this is wrong.  Feminism historically is looking at unfair treatment of women BUT this does not mean the unfair treatment of men for the SAME thing should be ignored.  Her refrigerator trope was her first video I saw actually but she failed to mention that male characters are often and used in no less and probably more capacity as nothing but backdrops for the protagonist.  This means women are not being unfairly treated, ie not being solely targeted just because they are a female.  It is not a valid argument to say so what because we have more male protagonists.  This does not mean women characters are unfairly treated as backdrops it means women are not getting enough protagonist roles which is a completely different argument.

I saw her argument as nothing more than looking at working conditions in a factory and only focusing how women are being treated then demanding that bad treatment end.  Meanwhile all the male workers are being treated like shit.  This is where modern feminism has derailed itself because it is going beyond the removing unfair treatment of women to where men are not being treated in this same unfair capacity and working towards equality but looking for preferential treatment of one gender over another.   This is probably my initial attraction to the Sargonites but as I said they just took it way too far and became this alternative facts machine.  I began to notice the types of commentators they attracted on their channels.   As I said previously it went from skepticism to ideologues.  Brexit was a more of a fuck you.  No reason in who this was going to fuck over or any depth of rational thought.  Just a big fuck you, I want to see the other side lose their shit and know I caused it.  Then the US primaries hit and I just had to turn them off.  It is hard to look at Carl's smug face.  As well as Bearing and this whole bearded dude in a tutu going into the girls bathroom because he just wanted to be a girl that day so he could molest little girls argument they constantly wanted to throw around.  Talk about completely misrepresenting the issue.  Again, jumped the shark into ideologues.

replies.text: @beayn Can we criticize the right without the whataboutism?  The Left has a lot of internal squabbling and self reflection.  The Right appears to lack any ability to self reflect.  I have  been doing this shit for 30 plus years and we can sit and bash and analyze the Left forever but every time we give any criticism towards the Right it is always ... always, met with well the Left does this too or what about crooked Hillary or the favorite canard of both parties are exactly, EXACTLY the same when no they are not. replies.author: @beayn
@DevinMacGregor
replies.text:
@beayn LOL, I watched Sargon for years and never say him actually admit he was wrong.   Why are you defending him?  Does he owe you money or something?

I have been arguing this stuff for over 30 years and no the camps do have differences.  I love the coin analogy because if you look at either side of any coin they are not the same.  Maybe instead of trying to lecture me you should actually look at a coin.  The main two parties yes have similarities but they do have differences.

I have my own opinions and the reason why I initially sought the Sargonites was because of my own differences with my own side.  It was when I saw them jump the shark is when I changed the channel.  And no those typically on the right do not self reflect.  They tend to be more into whataboutisms.  I have been in purely left groups who will rail into one another and I have been in groups with a large number of RWers and they are tribal. Very tribal.  You will hear Maher talk about the purity police on the Left and this is the Left eating its own.  I myself have mentioned it before. It is an issue on the Left.

Which is what I argued before as to one reason why the GOP wins a lot because their base is again very tribal and will rally the flag more than those on the left who often are like cats.

replies.author: @beayn
replies.text:
@DevinMacGregor >>LOL, I watched Sargon for years and never say him actually admit he was wrong.   Why are you defending him?  Does he owe you money or something?

I guess we didn't see the same videos? 

>>I have been arguing this stuff for over 30 years and no the camps do have differences.

I've been at it for about 25 years. Not everyone is a youngin around here.

>> I love the coin analogy because if you look at either side of any coin they are not the same. 

Of course not. They are different in what they believe, but they are the same in many respects. The horseshoe theory is valid here as well. The have the same reactionary responses to different ideas, but basically behave the same way, save for a few issues I'll mention below.

>>Maybe instead of trying to lecture me you should actually look at a coin.  The main two parties yes have similarities but they do have 
differences.

I'm not the one lecturing, you are. I'm simply disagreeing.  You're the one stating your opinions as fact and getting annoyed that I'm not towing the line.

I disagree that the right is more tribal than the left. The fact that they "eat their own" isn't because they self reflect, it's because they're TOO tribal.  Back in the old days you could hold 5/10 left wing beliefs and still be considered left wing. Today you must hold 10/10 left wing beliefs or you're rejected... hence "eating their own" because many of them find out they don't agree on 100% of everything, or new ideas come out that one must adhere to right away or be ejected from the tribe.

Right wing "whataboutisms" is used often, I agree... however I disagree about the reasons for it.  The main reason in my opinion is because the left is so damn hypocritical, loaded with double standards that they apply to one group and not another. The right tends to avoid this while staying consistent, wanting the same standards for everyone. This is why they use "But what about the left doing this" because the standard is always different.

This is why the right is more logical and more appealing these days to many people.  Most logical people think that being fair and unbiased is the best course of action while the left advocates double standards and total bias, while masquerading as "equality".

replies.author: @MP-db9sw
replies.text: Society cannot have a moral compass. Society isnt a conscious entity- it is an amalgamation of many entities. Individuals have their personal moral structures. Individuals move though their lives, acting out the axioms of their moral structures. When enough individuals interact and organize with each other, we call that a society. Observing the aggregate of all of these actions and interactions, one will find all kinds of tendencies and trends. Thats not ‚Äúsociety‚Äù having a moral system; it is society _reflecting_ the moral systems of its members.

I'm an anarcho-communist. Or a communo-Anarchist.  Or an anarcho-syndicalist, some days.

The hilarious thing is, right wing libertarians and I get along on half our issues.  The other half is them harboring deep misperceptions about what capitalism is and does for them, and how corporate hegemonies fit into that picture.

As a communist, I can assure you Bernie Sanders and AOC aren't communists.  They're moderate democratic socialists who want to maintain capitalism while regulating corporations for the benefit of society.

That's quite different from what I believe.  Just as an aside.  Communism and capitalism are irreconcilable. Communism does not tolerate private property in the form of corporations.

I assure you AOC isn't trying to end corporations in the US.  I, however, am.
